text: A YOUNG COUPLE on a bed, with a year-old BABY between the Light diffuses through thin curtains over a large window the young parents delight in the child, playing with her. Rustin Cohle, 26, with his WIFE and daughter--
Who knows why we choose the ones we do? Some just have your name on them. Like a bullet. Or a nail in the road. Off the happiness of the parents and their baby--

The established interview room- old table, bulletin board institutional walls. RUSTIN COHLE, 51, sits before us, th BEERS into his six pack, cigarettes beside a mug. The fla and-dice TATTOO visible on his forearm, he speaks into th camera, drinks, smokes--

...-Sorry. I drift when I have a few. S’why I like to drink alone. He finishes the can-- COHLE (CONT’D) Still won’t tell me about the new one..? Alright. None of my business, you guys don’t want to fill me in. He waits a beat, watching his questioner, pops open a new beer--  COHLE (CONT’D) None of my business, you tell me you lost most of our old files ina basement flood...

ON a black, unmarked CID car cruising through the Ozark foothills. Rust Cohle, 31, rides passenger as MARTIN HART 36, drives them into a frosty, rural landscape, pine-cove hills marked with dirt driveways, trailer parks and ramshackle homes, dense woods and hazed mountains in the distance. Dollops of SNOW spotting the edges of things--
We dug up the victim’s mother after talking to her ex in Pine Bluff. Piece of work, that guy.

A dilapidated CINDERBLOCK BUNGALOW with corrugated metal roof, its small yard a tangle of knee-high weeds and debr Cardboard covers one of the front windows. Cohle and Hart step out their car in the high grass, move toward the hou

A WOMAN, 60s, opens a plywood front door for the detectiv She's thick, stone-faced with her thin gray hair pulled i a greasy pony-tail, a tent-like house dress making a soli mound of her. From the darkened doorway she squints upwar the detectives, into the daylight--

Rust, Martin, and the WOMAN (ELLEN LEWIS), sit on ancient furniture in a cramped LIVING ROOM. Ellen is weeping, wip her eyes as Rust and Martin exchange a glance-- They look around the house, NOTICE a very old TV in one corner, and in another, a VOTIVE KNEELER before a STATUE the Virgin Mary, the statue framed by flea-market PORTRAI of Christ and the Madonna. Cast iron STOVE, makeshift chi with ash gathered beneath it in a pile. On a shelf, a few family PHOTOGRAPHS--
Far as helping us find out what happened, Mrs. Lewis. Maybe you could remember the last time you saw your daughter? Ellen dabs at her eyes with a rag--
It'd be... maybe a month, I think. Last time. She brought me some supper.
She call since then?

I- I don’t have a phone. Ellen turns to the kneeler, the portraits above it-- ELLEN (CONT’D) Bright Lady! What else do you want?! She breaks down again, gathers herself. Meanwhile Hart lo uncomfortably at Cohle, but Rust’s eyes are tracking deta of the house-- Soot-stains on the low ceiling, dirt, dust, old newspaper ON the row of PHOTOS on the shelf-- a young girl that mus DORA LANGE, wearing an inscrutable expression. In one pho she’s about twelve, and a MAN stands behind her, shadowed
Mrs. Lewis... how about her father? Did they have a relationship?
Him? Why? What did she say?
No, Mrs. Lewis, we're asking if he’s around, if they were close.
Why wouldn’t a father bathe his child? Glances between the partners and Ellen--
...Is your husband here? Can we talk to him? She becomes solemn, shakes her head, sets her jaw proudly
Died on the road. Drove a Peterbilt, rolled over when he took an exit too fast. Outside of Rowan, Oklahoma. May 11th, 1984.
What about the last time you saw Dora? What was she like-- how’d she seem, I mean?

...-She’s had a little trouble. But I thought there'd be time yet, for her. I waited. She said she’d started going to church. Said she'd been talking to a priest-- She chokes. Detectives exchange looks, Hart re-taking lea
She have any specific reason for seeing you, last time she came around?
.»-No. No, she said she just hadn’t been by in awhile. Brought me spaghetti... She knows I don’t have any money, if that’s what you mean.
How about her ex-husband, Charlie Lange?
Him? He’s in prison.
You get along with him?

...They both growed up together... They always want more, you know, kids... How do you keep them from wanting what’s bad for them?.. Why’d the Lord make people this way? That we can only want what hurts us? They give her some space with her desperation, then--
...She seem to be doing alright, last time you saw her?

She seemed alright. Yes. A little happier. More positive. I was glad she'd been talking to a priest.  At once, Ellen clutches her head, grimaces as if in the throws of a terrible migraine. She groans. Hart moves to side--
Mrs. Lewis?

..-My headaches. I get storms... NOTICE Rust continues watching her interaction with Hart impassively, almost coldly. Gradually, she pushes out of pain-- ELLEN (CONT’D) Worked at a dry-cleaners twenty years. Now I get headaches. I had to handle all these chemicals for such a long time. That’s what’s wrong with my nails-- She holds out her hands, shows her NAILS; they’re yellow gnarled, fungal, and the ends are soft and rotted off-- Creepsville. Off Cohle and Hart’s look to one another--

ON the detectives’ car as it travels southward on Highway through the wintry geography of the Ozark foothills. Hart drives, Rust sits back, staring ahead, thinking to himsel Hart clocks Rust in thought, and as if the silence bother him--
Piece of work, right? My mother, Donna Reed type. Hot meals. Lunches packed. Rust doesn’t respond-- HART (CONT’D) ++-Your mom still alive?

.»..-I guess so. The answer jabs Hart, Cohle’s indifference taken as an inchoate stab against family values. Cohle doesn’t engage further, keeps thinking to himself. Visibly annoyed, Hart turns back to the road--
My parents?
MARTIN HART, 56, suited, robust, speaks to his interviewe

My father, you know, I had about six inches on him, and even when he got old, I’d still say he could take me... Cobbler. Sold shoes. Made shoes. Navy in World War Two. Swam to North Africa when his PT Boat went down... There is a kind of boyish pride in Hart’s tale, informed matrix of private inflations-- HART (CONT’D) He was tough. But fair. You always knew where you stood with him... Cancer. ‘95. Mom passed a couple months after him. Married forty-two years. A conservative idealization of marriage and parenting is discernible in Hart’s recollection. He watches the camera though being asked a question-- HART (CONT’D) No. Rust’s mom lived somewhere out West, and he didn’t talk about his Dad... To me, looking back, the family stuff... I think part of Rust’s problem was that he needed things he wouldn’t admit to. On that succinct analysis--
ESTABLISHING-- a rural GAS STATION surrounded by desolate fields and dark forest, snow-dappled. Tires, car parts, junkyard effluvium. NOTICE the black CID CAR parked at th entrance--

FOLLOW along the store counter, its pornography and tobac and cheap impulse buys, to the end, where Cohle and Hart stand over a store ATTENDANT, CARLA EUSTICE--  She's large, corn-fed and plain, wearing a work vest and sitting in a chair at the end of the counter, crying as t detectives look down. Though on duty, she drinks from a f 40 OZ. of malt liquor--

--And the worst is that I had a feeling. Like maybe something was wrong with Dora and I should call her-- Carla looks to Cohle and Hart for assurance. A ribbon of TATTOOED STARS winds out of her collar and halfway up her neck--
You remember the last time you talked to her, Carla? Last time you saw her?

She came by my place. She needed somewheres to crash, and I let her spend the night... Charlie needed some cash. I told him she wouldn’t be able to help, but I gave her the message. Told her to call him.
She was homeless?

No, not the way she said it. She seemed, it don’t matter now, but I guess she’d gotten into the christy again. Or something. She said it was just for the night. I hadn’t seen her in a long time, and I could tell things were hard on her. I shoulda helped out more. I had a feeling...
You clean, Carla? Carla's eyes dart. She shrugs, almost ashamed, drinks--
Don’t worry about that. What’d she say to you? How was she?
Thin. Loopy, like I’m saying. On something... (MORE )

Oh- like this nursery rhyme? I woke up in the night cause I heard her. She’s curled on the couch. Blanket pulled up. And she was repeating this rhyme... I think I’d heard it before. Something like, ‘I met a man on the stairs, but he wasn’t there or anywheres.’ I don’t know. Weird. I went back to bed.
...’Yesterday upon the stair, I met a man who wasn’t there... He wasn’t there again today.’
That’s it.
...’I wish, I wish he’d go away.’ She looks between the two detectives, Hart watching Cohle explanation-- COHLE (CONT’D) It’s a poem. Antigonish. Hart slightly baffled, back to Carla--
You have any idea where she might’ve been staying? Landlord at her last address said she moved out about a year ago.

Yeah. No, she moved out of there. She might’ve had a fella for awhile? There’s this, like, women’s shelter? It’s outside Fayetteville, um, up near the highway before Springdale. I know she went there sometimes. Where the Wal-Mart is.
How far back you and Dora go, as friends?
Since junior high.
You knew her father?  Carla drinks--
...You gonna ask about the baths? Cohle and Hart show no reaction. A beat as Carla hits her
...-I can sense things sometimes... Do you- do you think I knew this was going to happen to Dora..?
She looks between the two cops, pleading for acquittal-- Cohle just shrugs--

Late afternoon. Hart drives as Cohle watches out the wind always observing the icy landscape. FROST covers the glas and light ripples and bounces off the ice-- Cohle’s POV FX: a small BIRD appears within the frost, flickering, its wings rising to the light, flapping once before it evaporates to runny ice on the glass-- Almost a trick of the light-- ON COHLE, shutting his eyes hard, as if fighting the visi
...We’re doing this wrong.
Your expert opinion.
We're trying to learn more about her. We should be trying to learn more about him.
There’s nothing to go on with him.
Hits up prosts. Self-hating. Artistic. Possibly trained in taxidermy. Religiously inclined.
Every person within a thousand miles is religiously inclined.  10.
(to self) ...Unless... was he mocking? Hart watches Cohle sort through his own thoughts--
Listen, I can appreciate a kind of academic model you’re adding here--

She sounds sad, Marty. A tired, ripped-up person on her last legs. Made her a good target for our man, but it wasn’t personal. Prost yards would be his hunting grounds. We should be on that, put Demma and Lutz on victim background.
Ninety-five percent of murders are committed by someone the victim knows.

And in what percentage of those murders does the DB have wings soldered to their back? Hart scowls, doesn’t retort, acknowledging the point-- COHLE (CONT’D) I’m telling you, there’s a scope to this. A vision. She was just chum in the water. We should be working on methodology. The car passes out of frame, but the camera lingers on th ice-laced hills under a deep gray sky, as though they wat us back--
Martin Hart, 56, speaks to the camera--

...Well, you're looking for a narrative. That’s the job. You’re just trying to find the story that fits. Crime scene protocols. Interrogate potential witnesses. Parcel evidence. Talk to people. Talk to everybody. Establish a timeline. Build a story... Days. (MORE )
Weeks. That’s still how it’s done, yeah..? You talk to people. Off his point--

Inside an empty STRIP CLUB where a homely woman gyrates lethargically on a pole for no audience. A MANAGER (40s) speaks to Cohle and Hart near the bar. The Manager holds PHOTOCOPY of Dora Lange’s mug shot--
Gave her a couple day shifts. She only showed up for one. Wasn’t good- looking enough to put up with that kind of shit. ON Cohle, scrutinizing the man’s face as he hands back th mug shot--
Rustin Cohle, 51, semi-relaxed with his beer--

You fill in blanks. Try to account for the state of things using objective correlatives... Like historians, writing a secret history. ...That’s why you’re talking to me, yeah? On the slightest sense that he knows something his interviewers don’t-- EXT. WOMEN’S SHELTER, ARKANSAS - DAY Day shading toward evening. A small brick BUILDING in a rundown patch of county between Fayetteville and Springda Arkansas. Cohle and Hart stand at the front door, looking at a sign which reads ‘ST. JOHN’S HOUSE OF WOMEN’ - ‘Love Shelter abide Within’--

Next on our tour of female tragedy... INT. WOMEN’S SHELTER, KITCHEN - DAY Inside the home’s KITCHEN, Cohle and Hart stand before a casually-dressed NUN (60s) and FOUR WOMEN, aged 25-40, wh share TWO PHOTOCOPIES of Dora Lange’s mug shot between th  12. Dishes and food suggest that the Nun was directing the wo in preparing dinner prior to the detectives’ entrance. Th WOMEN seem reticent in the company
Yes. She’s been here. around of late-- Ha:
of the police-- sn’t been Maybe two weeks? Think that’s the last time I saw her.
She just come for dinner times. I don’t think she here.
a few stayed No. She didn’t stay here.
You all maybe know where stay? The women look between each other,
A lot of the women come here, they don’t have pe: places. she did shake their heads-- through rmanent The Nun puts down the photocopy and returns to preparing dinner--
..-I talked to Dori befo:
Me too.
Anybody know if she had boyfriend, a man? The woman glance at one another--
--She had a husband in Bluff, I think.
.-She asked me before, taking vows. (MORE )
re. a jail. Pine about  13.
She once asked me what it meant, being a bride of Christ. I remember that... The Nun moves to put a dish in the oven--
Not a serious inquiry, you understand... Something’s happened to her, yes? She and the other women face the detectives--
Happens now and then. Men of your vocation come see us. Ask questions. She makes the sign of the cross--

(to girls) We'll hold a mass for her, Sunday. The women nod to one another grimly-- I/E. WOMEN’S SHELTER, ARKANSAS - DAY FOLLOW the Nun as she leads the detectives out. Cohle and Hart clock the features of the home as they walk-- everyt old but immaculately clean, shelves full of books, many o them more progressive than one might expect, WOMEN appear and shrinking back into doorways at their presence--
Usually ten to fifteen here at one time. No room for more than that. Get more for the meals. I’1l pass Dora's picture around.
And you got our cards. Anybody remembers anything, ring us up. Totally anonymous.
Anything at all. No matter how irrelevant it seems. She opens the door and the two detectives step outside--  14.
A lot of the women here have problems trusting men... I’1l do what I can.
They can trust us. The Nun looks over Cohle and seems flatly unimpressed. Sh just steps back, watching him as though she glimpsed a threat, shutting the door-- Cohle and Hart walk back to their car--
You got a way with folks, Rust. They warm up around you.
I make friends and influence people. They climb in the car--
Back in the HOMICIDE DIVISION of the State Police. DETECT milling about (DEMMA, LUTZ, GERACI, FAVRE). LT. QUESADA talking on the phone--

See what the other boys had before we called it a day. Hart and Cohle enter the squad room, acknowledged by the RECEPTIONIST. They walk through the division toward the B BOARD established for the Dora Lange Case-- Demma and Geraci approach Hart--

Landlord said she moved out a year ago. Lost the deposit. Never heard from her. Neighbors check out. Only ones remembered her said she used to come home in the mornings. A lot. Demma’s eyes are a little glazed, and he and Geraci displ the barest physical signs of inebriation--
Thanks.  15.
(sniffs) You two canvas the bars pretty heavy?
Up your ass, Cohle. Do your own legwork, you rat fuck.
What’d you call me?
S'what’s going on here, right? (re Cohle) Company Man here’s working CID for the Feds. Cohle puts his finger in Geraci’s face--
One time. Say it again rummy. Geraci lunges at Cohle, who side-steps and bitch-slaps th back of his head. Then Hart and LT. QUESADA are between t two, shoving them apart--
What the hell is this?!
(to Geraci) Goddamnit, Jerry. Go home. Geraci backs down, straightens his tie--
Nothing, Loo. Breaking balls. Hart looks at Cohle, who’s eye-fucking Geraci. NOTICE tha one likes matching stares with Cohle for very long. Gerac and Demma walk out the squad room, snide--
New kid likes talkin out the side of his mouth. Quesada stays with Hart and Cohle, awaiting explanation. LUTZ and FAVRE approach, Lutz reading from his notepad--
Got a couple hits from working girls. Nothing special. (MORE )
Nobody close to her. Few names recognized her as an occasional.
Like she tricked only now and then. Show up at a couple truck stops when she needed the cash. Got the names of which ones.
Right.
(to Cohle and Hart) What about you two? You get anything today? Cohle and Hart look at one another, mutually acknowledgin failure--
Martin Hart, 56, speaking to the camera--
Few days like that. We ask around, talk to other working girls. Talk to her former employers...
A large grocery store where the MANAGER (40s) speaks to t two detectives--
Had her on checkout. She quit after a few months. No notice. He shrugs, returns to stocking cans on a shelf--
Hart and Cohle sit at a booth with ANNE (30s), whose appearance suggests a cut-rate streetwalker--

She told me about where she came from. Her dad... But I never knew her that close. Sorry to hear what happened. Cohle rubs his eyes as though he has a headache--  17. INT. COHLE’S APARTMENT - DAY Early morning, cold, windows frosted. Rust Cohle rises to start his day. His bed is a mattress on the floor, surrou by books. No furnishings. A crucifix on the wall. FOLLOW to a narrow bathroom, it’s mirror as he stares at himself sleep-deprived, hollow-cheeked--
Days of nothing. That’s what it’s like, yeah? You work cases...
Early morning. In his big bed with his WIFE, MAGGIE, Hart happily woken by his TWO DAUGHTERS running into the room, bouncing on the bed. Embraces, tickling--
You talk, you listen, look for something to break. Days of searching. Like lost dogs... On the groggy, familial joy of Hart’s morning wake-up--

A MAN (50s) stands behind the counter inside a Taxidermis stuffed, mounted ANIMALS clogging the walls all around, g animals- deer, duck, quail, a bear’s head. Cohle and Hart stand on the other side, asking the MAN a question, dialo only voice-over--
Talked to something like ten taxidermists. Nobody had ever done a turkey vulture, much less sold one. The Taxidermist shakes his head to answer their question-
Hart drives while Cohle looks over the NOTES that fill th big legal tablet he uses. Hart watches him peripherally, portfolio spread across his lap--
Hey. Other night, you were over for dinner... Why didn’t you go home, when I had Chris call for you?  18.
...-I don’t know. I guess I'd sobered up. And it wasn’t as bad as I thought, meeting your family. I liked talking to them.
‘Bad’? Why’d you think it’d be bad?
I didn’t. Look-- He closes his portfolio, sighs-- COHLE (CONT’D) I was married, Marty. Three years. We had a baby girl. She died, two years old. Car accident. Marriage couldn’t handle it.
Shit, man. I’m sorry. Sorry to hear that. I didn’t--

S'alright. It was just me, not you guys. I was worried... being around that kind of thing... After a beat, Rust goes back to looking at his notes, and Martin glances at him from the corner of his eyes, a new sympathy in his appraisal--
51, Rust Cohle smokes, listens to his interviewer. Perhap slightly buzzed, he speaks a little discursively when he answers--

Yeah. Just married once. Came close another time. That was later on. Marty introduced us. She broke it off. For the best. I gave her cause... I can be hard on people. He puts his cigarette out, thinks, sips his beer. In an o confessional outpouring-- COHLE (CONT’D) I can pick people apart. I don’t mean to. But I can be critical. I have problems getting angry... (MORE )

COHLE (CONT’D) I’ve had the thought before that I’m not good for other people. Like it’s no good for them to be around me long. I wear them down. They become unhappy. I don’t mean for that. But life works its way through you... I can’t say the job made me this way. More like, me being this way made me right for the job. I don’t know. I used to think about it a lot. Not so much now. You reach an age and you understand who you are... A beat as he stares into the camera, unable to fully hide pathos in his eyes-- COHLE (CONT’D) It’s better now. I live in a little room out in the country. Tend bar four nights a week. In between I drink, and there’s nobody around to make me stop. Which is good. I understand who I am. After all these years... There’s a victory in that. Cohle’s flat gaze carries no sense of achievement--

The HOMICIDE SQUAD ROOM, fairly empty. NOTICE the BIG BOA and how little evidence has been added to the Dora Lange case. At their desk, Cohle is typing up the Daily Log-- ACROSS THE ROOM Hart speaks softly into the phone, trying to be heard--

(into phone) No, babe. I understand. Of course I want to be there... It’s just the case got moving, I needa follow something up tonight... Listen, you tell her Daddy’s proud, and I'1l see it next time... Alright, sorry. I love you. Marty hangs up. Walks across the room to where Cohle is typing-- HART (CONT’D) You alright doing the DL? I got somewhere to be.  20.
Boy's night at Glory Holez?
Nice. Audrey's piano recital.
Sure. Go on.

Thanks. Hart grabs his jacket and makes for the exit while Cohle regards him with a slight suspicion-- INT. SCARLET O’S TAVERN - NIGHT A mid-scale bar, dim, mostly attended by adults or the mi aged. Hart stands at the bar with Demma and Lutz, all thr drinking boilermakers--
10 to 1 we never get this guy.
You're giving yourself too much credit.
Don’t let Cohle hear you say that.
Fuck Cohle. He called my man Geraci incompetent.
Steve is incompetent.
You know he’s ex-DEA or something? S'why Willey forced him on our division. The feds are running something.
No, no. See, that’s you all starting shit, Chris. Bullshit rumor. Quesada already talked to him about it.
What a relief.  21. The BARTENDER delivers three whiskey shots to the men, wh all toast and throw them back. Hart starts moving away--
Where you going?
Make a call.
In a dark hallway, Hart leans against the wall, using the

(into phone) Alright if I drop by..? Scarlet O’s... No I’m not. I barely had anything to drink... Leave the door unlocked? He hangs up the phone, straightens his jacket. FOLLOW as walks back to the bar, the barest hint of conflict in his features--
I did. I enjoyed being married. When Cohle rejoins his buddies, he quickly fakes a grin--
Hart, 56, speaking to his interrogators--

I mean, sure, you miss some things, being a cop. And yeah, I probably could have worked it better than I did. But you know how it is. Things you see... You gotta decompress before you go being the family man. I mean, what’s in your head, you can’t have the kids around it... A beat-- HART (CONT’D) I’m saying, sometimes you’re not in a position to listen to twenty kids trying to play ‘chopsticks.’ This for my wife, too. She doesn’t want to be around me when I’m this way, juiced on a case. (MORE )
HART (CONT’D) So sometimes you go have a drink instead of going home... A tiny lie, as those things go. The kind that keeps the peace.
ESTABLISHING- a set of manufactured CONDOS in a suburban north of Fayetteville. Hart’s CAR parks at the curb. He climbs out, starts walking to a door--

I mean the first lesson of adulthood is compromise, right? EXT. LISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Hart has just knocked on a door, and it opens onto LISA TRAGNETTI, 26, dark-haired and sexy in shorts and a loose shirt. She smiles at Marty, who holds up a bottle of RUM. Lisa rolls her eyes as she steps aside for him to enter-- INT. LISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT ON a STENOGRAPH MACHINE, parked in one corner outside the living room at a desk with a stack of paper (this telling Lisa is a court reporter). MOVING into the living room, fairly tasteful, relatively cheap furnishings. A COFFEE T where the bottle of RUM stands-- A TELEVISION shows continuing coverage of the Exxon Valde oil spill-- Martin sits back on the couch as Lisa enters from the kit with two glasses of ice and a liter of Coke-- She starts to make the drinks, bending over in front of Marty, who reaches out and slides his hand up her shorts-
...That was part of Rust’s problem, like I’s saying. A man needs a family. She turns around and they start kissing, Martin yanking h shorts down--

INT. LISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT The drinks sit untouched on the coffee table, ice melted. Lisa lies on the couch with Marty, wearing only her T-shi  23. Hart’s in his boxers and undershirt, running fingers thro her hair--
...What’d you do last night? I called up here late.
What were you doing?
Working. Thought about dropping by. Where were you?
Out with girlfriends. Marty stops fondling her hair--
-+--I don’t like that.
What? You're jealous?
Don’t be stupid. I mean... there’s crazy people out there. A man killing young women.
..-Are you talking about that girl in Benton county again? In the paper?
(lying) ...Not just her. There’s more.
More? Really?
We're not saying. Keeping it out of the press. But we’re thinking he’s been doing it awhile. Still doing it.
Oh. Wow. Jeez.
There’s no need to be going out. Have a drink at home.  24.
I can’t meet a nice man at home.
That hurts me, see, when you say that. When you speak to me ina passive-aggressive way. I always talk straight with you.
Oh, excuse me. I meant, since you're married, I need to be considering my options as a young woman. I want things Marty. This is okay. But it won’t last on.
I want things, too. Lisa shakes her head, leans away, reaching for her drink-
You just want your cake and to eat it, too. Marty moves to her--
What the hell good is cake if you can’t eat it? He buries his face in her ass. She gasps, sets down the d and closes her eyes--
Rust Cohle, now on his last beer, telling his story--

Me? I told you. I didn’t sleep. Most nights I’d read manuals. Study. Go over case stuff... He drinks-- COHLE (CONT’D) Other times I’d just lie in the dark. Think about women. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT A cheap, cramped STUDIO apartment by the railtracks, the single room cluttered with loose clothing, fast food bags  25. A BED takes up most of the space, festooned with STUFFED TOYS, plush animals for which the WOMAN on the bed is muc too old-- Lucy (20s, the prostitute Cohle met in ep. 1), sits cross legged on the bed, a few baggies of PILLS in front of her prescription bottles without labels. Rust Cohle, 31, stan at her window, exhausted, looking out at a streetlight in alley--
You wanted blues?
Qualludes. The dopey stuff. He turns to watch her rifle through the pills-- COHLE (CONT’D) What’s it run?
Um... I’m thinking. I seen the blue go for three a pill.

We'll say two-hundred for all of them. Lucy blinks back disbelief: the cop’s not going to rip he off. Cohle hands her the money, which she takes wide-eyed cautiously-- Cohle examines the bottle of about sixty pills while Lucy watches, relaxing a little for the first time--
Thought you might just take them. Or that you wanted something else... Some kind of something else. She reclines on her bed, legs stretching under a denim sk bruises on her knees. An invitation--
No.

...Then I thought, you’re a good- lookin man. You wouldn’t need a shakedown to get some.  26. Lucy continues to watch Cohle as puts the cap back on the pills, stuffs them in his blazer pocket. During their interaction, Cohle remains civil but cold, unresponsive t her gestures. The light from the window is dowdy and oran dramatizing his edge-- LUCY (CONT’D) ...What’s your deal? SFX: SOUND of a BOTTLE BREAKING outside the window-- Cohle moves to the window, sees down below a PERSON run i SHADOWS across the street, disappearing--
I don’t have a deal.
I mean, what you do. You’re not like cops I know. Even the bad ones.
Who’re the bad ones?
..-Nevermind... I thought you was gonna bust me last week.
Not interested.
Yeah. I know. You’re kind of strange... Like you might be dangerous.

Of course I’m dangerous. I’m police. I can do terrible things to people with impunity. She goes quiet, and Cohle scans the stuffed toys on her b their paws and glass eyes an uncomfortable decoration-- COHLE (CONT’D) ..+-You remember that girl I first asked you about? The blonde? She nods--
I still ain’t heard nothing.  27.
You know anybody might’ ve?
